body: I think you might be able to completely eliminate `tseries/index/_str_to_dt_array` and instead just pass directly to `to_datetime` (you can leave this change though)
Currently removing `_str_to_dt_array` looks difficult, because it uses `parse_time_string` rather than `to_datetime`, and these functions have different logic / arguments.
I think give it a try. the perf diff is huge.
@sinhrks did you look at perf?
pushing, if you get 2 this in next day or 2 lmk
@sinhrks revist?

Sorry to delay. Removing `_str_to_dt_array` seems to be possible, but parsed result may be different because of inconsistencies in datetime parsing function.

Going to merge parsing function spec to solve this (changed the title so).

Fixed `to_datetime` and `Timestamp` docstring to have `dayfirst` and `yearfirst` descriptions. 

And last difference I noticed is the case input only has time string. Currently, this PR doesn't change the  current master's behavior below.

```
pd.Timestamp("16:15")
# 2014-08-16 16:15:00

pd.tseries.tools.to_datetime("16:15")
# 2014-08-16 16:15:00

pd.tseries.tools.parse_time_string("16:15")[0]
# 0001-01-01 16:15:00
```

ok this is fine
ping on green

API question: Is it needed that `Timestamp()` gets the `dayfirst` and `yearfirst` keywords? 
In the reasoning: keep `Timestamp` simple and if you want more flexible parsing, then there is `to_datetime` to use (+ if we add them, why not also other keywords of `to_datetime` such as `format`?).
Whichever, but I think `dayfirst` and `yearfirst` are more important than others as these are passed to dateutil.
@sinhrks something else, did you do a performance check? (as this touches quite some cython code)

There is maybe no real reason not to have it, but is there a good reason to have it? 

For me it feels like duplicating functionality for which there is no real need. Also, dayfirst being not strict and things like that, I don't know if we should encourage it.

If you have a program that has to parse a bunch of strings, then you use `to_datetime`. In my mind, the main usecase of directly calling `Timestamp` is when you just need to instantiate a certain datetime, and for that it is easy to provide a string (compared to the `datetime.datetime` constructor ..). But you also have direct control over the string you type in such case, and then is even more work to type `dayfirst=True` instead of just typing the date in the 'standard' format.

To be clear, I am also not strongly opposed to adding this, I just don't really see the need. But if there are other usecases where this would solve problems, then OK.
@sinhrks pls rebase. What's left here / what are the issues from above?
@sinhrks status?
@sinhrks status?

Is this PR in limbo? I just hit another case where I think this change would have helped out. (similar to #6961 , if you read a CSV with only year-month data it seems to use current day-of-month when filling out the date)
yep - want to pick it up (iirc it just needs to be scaled back a bit) don't add args to Timestamp

I also added those args back to the doc string in another PR.  Whoever picks up this PR, please put a comment in the source code referencing the PRs saying we don't want to add dayfirst and yearfirst to the doc string.  This will save having the same discussion yet another time.

@sinhrks ok I think we need to resurrect this (and just be minimal about its changes), or close.

thoughts?
Sorry, I'll revisit this. I have to understand `parse_time_string` little more to finish this.
OK, I think it is ready for review once again. I've attached summary on the top.

looks really good

can u run a vbench ?

Really nice clean-up!

Added some comments, and also a question about the `freq` keyword. You now made a `_to_datetime` to have this keyword, but is there a reason to not have this keyword in `to_datetime` itself?
Also something else: I don't think we should target 0.16.1 here, as there are some changes in parsing behaviour for some cases.
@sinhrks this does clean up a bunch of stuff. can you run a perf check just to make sure. Let's move to 0.17.0 and put in first thing.
I've did further simplification at my local, but still have a performance regression like vbench attached above. I'll once summarize the changes after fixing the perf.
